comment_body:
> Fix: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/issues/20368

I’d use the tag *Resolves:*.

> Ref: https://lore.kernel.org/stable/20241001112035.973187-1-idosch@nvidia.com/t/#u

Please summarize the discussion. Best cite @idosch’s explanation from his first reply to Greg.

> But first of, why?  Why not just take the upstrema commits instead?
> 
> thanks,
> greg k-h

Ido:
> There were a lot of changes as part of the 6.3 cycle to completely
> rework the semantics of the devlink instance reference count. As part of
> these changes, commit d77278196441 ("devlink: bump the instance index
> directly when iterating") inadvertently fixed the bug mentioned in this
> patch. This commit cannot be applied to 6.1.y as-is because a prior
> commit (also in 6.3) moved the code to a different file (leftover.c ->
> core.c). There might be more dependencies that I'm currently unaware of.
> 
> The alternative, proposed in this patch, is to provide a minimal and
> contained fix for the bug introduced in upstream commit c2368b19807a
> ("net: devlink: introduce "unregistering" mark and use it during
> devlinks iteration") as part of the 6.0 cycle.

Summary of https://lore.kernel.org/stable/20241001112035.973187-1-idosch@nvidia.com/t/#u
Thanks. But I meant to put that into the merge/pull request and commit message description.
@bingwang-ms Can this me merged?

msn2100 platform. upstream code is refactored and patch cannot be applied directly. https://github.com/gregkh/linux/commit/d35df77707bf5ae1221b5ba1c8a88cf4fcdd4901.

It seems safe to revert the offending commit than to make an effort to port the upstream change into the stable branch. 

I'll ofcourse change this once the upstream commit is backported to 6.1 branch

Please elaborate. What device? How did you test, that the devices work now?
Please rebase your branch instead of merging the branch *master* into it.

> Please rebase your branch instead of merging the branch _master_ into it.

OK， I have executed ‘git rebase origin/master’ and ‘git push’ again，thanks.

> > They are independent macros that require support from kernel drivers
> 
> Macros?
> 
> Please elaborate. What device? How did you test, that the devices work now?

CONFIG_SENSORS_ISL68137 and CONFIG_SENSORS_INA3221 are used in the Micas W6510-48V device. The detailed verification process is shown in the attachment；
CONFIG_EEPROM_93XX46 and CONFIG_SPI_INTEL_PCI will be used in other Micas devices and will be submitted later. Thanks!
[ina3221.log](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16262930/ina3221.log)
[isl68137.log](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16262933/isl68137.log)

No idea, why more commits are shown on GitHub.

It’d be nice, if you amended the merge/pull request description.

>

Original PR: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-linux-kernel/pull/397

> This certainly fixes the immediate problem of kernel corruption, however it may have implications for low memory devices with high transceiver counts. The writebuf is completely unused in the use_smbus != 0 case, so an optimization might be to handle that specific case. For the pure i2c controllers using i2c_transfer, I had also considered reallocating in the sysfs write function, however that gets tricky with interactions with optoe_eeprom_write (as we don't want to hold a lock across the timeout retry loop). Finally, another option might be to have a stack based buffer in optoe_eeprom_write for small transfers, and dynamcally allocate/free within optoe_eeprom_write for large transfers (and avoid any allocation at all in the probe function). But again, this solution solves the immediate problem of kernel corruption, at the expense of more memory usage.

@billie-alsup I had thought about this and I would prefer to keep the memory allocation once, instead of resizing the memory buffer size to the optoe's write data size causing fragmentation at runtime. I am doing a trade-off between memory (128 bytes * 128 physical ports) = 16KB waste vs memory fragmentation and simplicity that comes with static allocation.

reopen this PR to run pipeline.

That is why we have dsc-linux-patches

> Thank you for your patch. I’d be great if you could amend the git commit message summary and merge/pull request title to use imperative mood and _to enable_ or _for_:
> 
> > Disable small sector erase size for UBIFS on flash
> 
> Also could you please copy the merge/pull request description to the commit message?
> 
> I’d use Markdown to format the description, and, for example, indent code blocks by four spaces.
> 
> ```
> # mount | grep obfl
> ubi0 on /mnt/obfl type ubifs (rw,relatime,assert=read-only,ubi=0,vol=0)
> ```
> 
> And just a tip, that `findmnt -n /mnt/obfl` does the same. (`-n` suppresses the printing of the header.)

@paulmenzel , Pls check updates
@bmridul Why a filesystem like UBIFS is limited by Nand's/NOR's erase size? What error are you seeing with this config enbled?

@bmridul any reference for this claim:
`UBIFS does not work on NOR Flash with small sector erasesize`
@bmridul why should UBIFS care the underlying media NOR or NAND

> @bmridul Why a filesystem like UBIFS is limited by Nand's/NOR's erase size? What error are you seeing with this config enbled?

Basically the ubiattach command fails with errors..

    **[  145.820167] ubi0 error: validate_vid_hdr [ubi]: bad data_size
    [  145.826621] ubi0 error: validate_vid_hdr [ubi]: bad VID header**
    [  145.833163] Volume identifier header dump:
    [  145.837752]  magic     55424921
    [  145.841270]  version   1
    [  145.844109]  vol_type  1
    [  145.846934]  copy_flag 1
    [  145.849775]  compat    5
    [  145.852609]  vol_id    2147479551
    [  145.856318]  lnum      0
    [  145.859146]  data_size 22016
    [  145.862370]  used_ebs  0
    [  145.865207]  data_pad  0
    [  145.868044]  sqnum     1
    [  145.870869]  hdr_crc   11f8b00c
    [  145.874390] Volume identifier header hexdump:
    **[  145.879362] ubi0 error: ubi_io_read_vid_hdr [ubi]: validation failed for PEB 2064**
    [  145.891655] ubi0 error: ubi_attach_mtd_dev [ubi]: failed to attach mtd4, error -22

With the fix, we are able to mount the flash and access the file system contents.

Why not just cite the line from the Kconfig description?

> From the description of `CONFIG_MTD_SPI_NOR_USE_4K_SECTORS`:
> 
> > Please note that some tools/drivers/filesystems may not work with 4096 B erase size (e.g. UBIFS requires 15 KiB as a minimum).

Also, I’d appreciate the UBIFS “error” messages in the commit message too, so should somebody hit this error, it is easily found in the git history/log.
@paulmenzel / @saiarcot895 can we help merge of this
Thank you.

Ah, I was trying to figure out why the PR checkers didn't fail, but we don't have a PR check for secure boot yet.

> Thank you for your patch. Some small nits:
> 
> 1. The [official spelling seems to be _BlueField_](https://www.nvidia.com/en-us/networking/products/data-processing-unit/).
> 2. Please split the commit into two.
> 3. Please amend the commit message to remove the trailing dot from the commit message summary/title, and to give a little more background about the system. For example, would BlueField-2 now also be supported?

Thank you Paul for your feedback. 
1. Both `Bluefield` and `BlueField` are correct spellings as well as BF-3. I prefer `Bluefield`
2. The default merge strategy in the repository is "squash". Even if I split the changes into two commits they will be squashed together during PR merge. Instead, I split the changes into separate PR: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-linux-kernel/pull/381
3. Only BF-3 is supported. We have no plans to add BF-2 support.
